qas.question: Which state send members to the parliament in Edinburgh?
What type of government does the United Kingdom and the Crown Dependencies have?
Who shares power in Northern Ireland?
Unionists in Northern Ireland want to remain part of which country?
Nationalist in Northern Ireland want to join which country?
Ireland, the UK and the 3 Crown Dependencies are socialistic democracies with what?
Ireland, the UK and Great Britain are parliamentary democracies with what?
What type of system does Southern Ireland use to make decisions?
The Irish monarch is the head of state for all parts of the isles except?
The President of the United Kingdom is the head of state for which Republic?

context: Ireland, the United Kingdom and the three Crown Dependencies are all <a1_0>parliamentary democracies<a1_0/>, with <b5_0><b6_0>their own separate parliaments<b6_0/><b5_0/>. All parts of the United Kingdom return members to parliament in London. In addition to this, voters in <a0_0>Scotland<a0_0/>, Wales and Northern Ireland return members to a parliament in Edinburgh and to assemblies in Cardiff and Belfast respectively. Governance in the norm is by majority rule, however, Northern Ireland uses <b7_0>a system of power sharing<b7_0/> whereby <a2_0>unionists and nationalists<a2_0/> share executive posts proportionately and where the assent of both groups are required for the Northern Ireland Assembly to make certain decisions. (In the context of Northern Ireland, unionists are those who want Northern Ireland to remain a part of the <a3_0>United Kingdom<a3_0/> and nationalists are those who want Northern Ireland join with <a4_0>the rest of Ireland<a4_0/>.) The British monarch is the head of state for all parts of the isles except for <b8_0>the <b9_0>Republic of Ireland<b8_0/>,<b9_0/> where the head of state is the President of Ireland.
